editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. King Edward IV Elizabeth; Queen to King Edward IV Edward; Prince of Wales; son to King Edward IV; afterwards King Edward V Richard; Duke of York; son to King Edward IV George; Duke of Clarence; brother to King Edward IV Richard; Duke of Gloucester; brother to King Edward IV; afterwards King Richard III Edward Plantagenet; son to Clarence Henry; Earl of Richmond; afterwards King Henry VII Duke of Buckingham Sir Richard Ratcliffe Anthony Woodeville; Earl Rivers; brother to Elizabeth Marquess of Dorset; son to Elizabeth Lord Grey; son to Elizabeth Lord Hastings Lord William Stanley; Earl of Derby Sir William Catesby Sir James Tyrell Sir Robert Brackenbury; Lieutenant of the Tower Queen Margaret; widow of King Henry VI Duchess of York; mother to King Edward IV Lady Anne; widow of Edward Prince of Wales; afterwards married to Richard Lady Margaret Plantagenet; daughter to Clarence Multiple Speakers
Cardinal Thomas Bourchier; Archbishop of Canterbury Thomas Rotherham; Archbishop of York John Morton; Bishop of Ely Duke of Norfolk Earl of Surrey Lord Lovel Earl of Oxford Sir James Blunt Sir Walter Herbert Sir Thomas Vaughn Christopher Urswick; a Priest John; a Priest Lord Mayor of London Sheriff of Wiltshire Ghost Henry VI
Gentleman First Murderer Second Murderer First Citizen Second Citizen Third Citizen First Messenger Pursuivant Scrivener Page Second Messenger Third Messenger Fourth Messenger

stage.l: Enter Richard Duke of Gloster, solus.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: NOw is the Winter of our Discontent,
Made glorious Summer by this Son of Yorke:
And all the clouds that lowered upon our house
In the deep bosom of the Ocean buried.
Now are our brows bound with Victorious Wreathes,
Our bruised arms hung up for Monuments;
Our stern Alarums changed to merry Meetings;
Our dreadful Marches, to delightful Measures.
Grim visaged War, hath smoothed his wrinkled Front:
And now, instead of mounting Barbed Steeds,
To fright the Souls of fearful Adversaries,
He capers nimbly in a Ladies Chamber,
To the lascivious pleasing of a Lute.
But I, that am not shaped for sportive tricks,
Nor made to court an amorous Looking-glass:
I, that am Rudely stamped, and want love's Majesty,
To strut before a wanton ambling Nymph:
I, that am curtailed of this fair Proportion,
Cheated of Feature by dissembling Nature,
Deformed, unfinished, sent before my time
Into this breathing World, scarce half made up,
And that so lamely and unfashionable,
That dogs bark at me, as I halt by them.
Why I (in this weak piping time of Peace)
Have no delight to pass away the time,
Unless to see my Shadow in the Sun,
And descant on mine own Deformity.
And therefore, since I cannot prove a Lover,
To entertain these fair well spoken days,
I am determined to prove a Villain,
And hate the idle pleasures of these days.
Plots have I laid, Inductions dangerous,
By drunken Prophesies, Libels, and Dreams,
To set my Brother Clarence and the King
In deadly hate, the one against the other:
And if King Edward be as true and just,
As I am Subtle, False, and Treacherous,
This day should Clarence closely be mewed up:
About a Prophecy, which says that G,
Of Edwards heirs the murtherer shall be.
Dive thoughts down to my soul, here Clarence comes.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Brother, good day: What means this armed guard
That waits upon your Grace?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: His Majesty tendering my persons safety,
Hath appointed this Conduct, to convey me to the Tower

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Upon what cause?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Because my name is George.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Alack my Lord, that fault is none of yours:
He should for that commit your Godfathers.
O belike, his Majesty hath some intent,
That you should be new Christened in the Tower,
But what is the matter Clarence, may I know?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Yea Richard, when I know: but I protest
As yet I do not: But as I can learn,
He hearkens after Prophesies and Dreams,
And from the Cross-row plucks the letter G:
And says, a Wizard told him, that by G,
His issue disinherited should be.
And for my name of George begins with G,
It follows in his thought, that I am he.
These (as I learn) and such-like toys as these,
Hath moved his Highness to commit me now.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Why this it is, when men are ruled by Women:
It is not the King that sends you to the Tower,
My Lady Grey his Wife, Clarence it is she.
That tempts him to this harsh Extremity.
Was it not she, and that good man of Worship,
Anthony Woodeulle her Brother there,
That made him send Lord Hastings to the Tower?
From whence this present day he is delivered?
We are not safe Clarence, we are not safe.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: By heaven, I think there is no man secure
But the Queen's Kindred, and night-walking Heralds,
That trudge betwixt the King, and Mistress Shore.
Heard you not what an humble Suppliant
Lord Hastings was, for her delivery?

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Humbly complaining to her Deity,
Got my Lord Chamberlain his liberty.
I will tell you what, I think it is our way,
If we will keep in favour with the King,
To be her men, and wear her Livery.
The jealous overworn Widow, and herself,
Since that our Brother dubbed them Gentlewomen,
Are mighty Gossips in our Monarchy.

sp.speaker: Brack.
sp.l: I beseech your Graces both to pardon me,
His Majesty hath straightly given in charge,
That no man shall have private Conference.
(Of what degree soever) with your Brother.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Even so, if please your Worship Brakenbury,
You may partake of anything we say:
We speak no Treason man; We say the King
Is wise and virtuous, and his Noble Queen
Well struck in years, fair, and not jealous.
We say, that Shores Wife hath a pretty Foot,
A cherry Lip, a bonny Eye, a passing pleasing tongue:
And that the Queen's Kindred are made gentle Folks.
How say you sir? can you deny all this?

sp.speaker: Brack.
sp.l: With this (my Lord) myself have nought to
do.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Naught to do with Mistress Shore?
I tell thee Fellow, he that doth naught with her
(Excepting one) were best to do it secretly alone.

sp.speaker: Brack.
sp.l: What one, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Her Husband Knave, wouldst thou betray me?

sp.speaker: Brack.
sp.l: I do beseech your Grace
To pardon me, and withal forbear
Your Conference with the Noble Duke.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: We know thy charge Brakenbury, and will obey.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: We are the Queen's abjects, and must obey.
Brother farewell, I will unto the King,
And whatsoever you will employ me in,
Were it to call King Edwards Widow, Sister,
I will perform it to enfranchise you.
Mean time, this deep disgrace in Brotherhood,
Touches me deeper than you can imagine.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I know it pleaseth neither of us well.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Well, your imprisonment shall not be long,
I will deliver you, or else lie for you:
Mean time, have patience.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I must perforce: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Go tread the path that thou shalt never return:
Simple plain Clarence, I do love thee so,
That I will shortly send thy Soul to Heaven,
If Heaven will take the present at our hands.
But who comes here? the new delivered Hastings?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: Good time of day unto my gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: As much unto my good Lord Chamberlain:
Well are you welcome to this open Air,
How hath your Lordship brooked imprisonment?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: With patience (Noble Lord) as prisoners must:
But I shall live (my Lord) to give them thanks
That were the cause of my imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: No doubt, no doubt, and so shall Clarence too,
For they that were your Enemies, are his,
And have prevailed as much on him, as you,

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: More pity, that the Eagles should be mewed,
Whiles Kites and Buzzards play at liberty.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: What news abroad?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: No news so bad abroad, as this at home:
The King is sickly, weak, and melancholy,
And his Physicians fear him mightily.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Now by Saint. Iohn, that News is bad indeed.
O he hath kept an evil Diet long,
And over-much consumed his Royal Person:
It is very grievous to be thought upon.
Where is he, in his bed?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: He is.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Go you before, and I will follow you.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: He cannot live I hope, and must not dye,
Till George be packed with post-horse up to Heaven.
I will in to urge his hatred more to Clarence,
With Lies well steeled with weighty Arguments,
And if I fail not in my deep intent,
Clarence hath not another day to live:
Which done, God take King Edward to his mercy,
And leave the world for me to bustle in.
For then, I will marry Warwickes youngest daughter.
What though I killed her Husband, and her Father,
The readiest way to make the Wench amends,
Is to become her Husband, and her Father:
The which will I, not all so much for love,
As for another secret close intent,
By marrying her, which I must reach unto.
But yet I run before my horse to Market:
Clarence still breathes, Edward still lives and reigns,
When they are gone, then must I count my gains.

stage.l: Enter the Coarse of Henrie the sixt with Halberds to guard it,

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Set down, set down your honourable load,
If Honour may be shrouded in a Hearse;
Whilst I awhile obsequiously lament
The untimely fall of Virtuous Lancaster.
Poor key-cold Figure of a holy King,
Pale Ashes of the House of Lancaster;
Thou bloodless Remnant of that Royal Blood,
Be it lawful that I invocate thy Ghost,
To hear the Lamentations of poor Anne,
Wife to thy Edward, to thy slaughtered Son,
Stabbed by the selfsame hand that made these wounds.
Lo, in these windows that let forth thy life,
I power the helpless Balm of my poor eyes.
O cursed be the hand that made these holes:
Cursed the Heart, that had the heart to do it:
Cursed the Blood, that let this blood from hence:
More direful hap betide that hated Wretch
That makes us wretched by the death of thee,
Than I can wish to Wolves, to Spiders, Toads,
Or any creeping venomed thing that lives.
If ever he have Child, Abortive be it,
Prodigious, and untimely brought to light,
Whose ugly and unnatural Aspect
May fright the hopeful Mother at the view,
And that be Heir to his unhappiness.
If ever he have Wife, let her be made
More miserable by the death of him,
Than I am made by my young Lord, and thee.
Come now towards Chertsey with your holy Lode,
Taken from Paules, to be interred there.
And still as you are weary of this weight,
Rest you, whiles I lament King Henries Coarse.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Stay you that bear the Coarse, and set it down.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: What black Magician conjures up this Fiend,
To stop devoted charitable deeds?

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Villains set down the Coarse, or by Saint. Paul,
I will make a Coarse of him that disobeys.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My Lord stand back, and let the Coffin pass.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Unmannered Dog,
Standest thou when I command:
Advance thy Halberd higher than my breast,
Or by Saint. Paul I will strike thee to my Foot,
And spurn upon thee Beggar for thy boldness.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: What do you tremble? are you all afraid?
Alas, I blame you not, for you are Mortal,
And Mortal eyes cannot endure the Devil.
Avaunt thou dreadful minister of Hell;
Thou hadst but power over his Mortal body,
His Soul thou canst not have: Therefore be gone.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Sweet Saint, for Charity, be not so cursed.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Foul Devil,
For Gods sake hence, and trouble us not,
For thou hast made the happy earth thy Hell:
Filled it with cursing cries, and deep exclaims:
If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds,
Behold this pattern of thy Butcheries.
O Gentlemen, see, see dead Henries wounds,
Open their congealed mouths, and bleed afresh.
Blush, blush, thou lump of foul Deformity:
For it is thy presence that exhales this blood
From cold and empty Veins where no blood dwells.
Thy Deeds inhumane and unnatural,
Provokes this Deluge most unnatural.
O God! which this Blood madest, revenge his death:
O Earth! which this Blood drinkest, revenge his death.
Either Heaven with Lightning strike the murtherer dead:
Or Earth gape open wide, and eat him quick,
As thou dost swallow up this good Kings blood,
Which his Hell-governed arm hath butchered.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Lady, you know no Rules of Charity,
Which renders good for bad, Blessings for Curses.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Villain, thou knowest nor law of God nor Man,
No Beast so fierce, but knows some touch of pity.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: But I know none, and therefore am no Beast.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: O wonderful, when devils tell the truth!

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: More wonderful, when Angels are so angry:
Vouchsafe (divine perfection of a Woman)
Of these supposed Crimes, to give me leave
By circumstance, but to acquit myself.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Vouchsafe (defused infection of man)
Of these known evils, but to give me leave
By circumstance, to curse thy cursed Self.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Fairer than tongue can name thee, let me have
Some patient leisure to excuse myself.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Fouler than heart can think thee,
Thou canst make no excuse currant,
But to hang thyself.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: By such despair, I should accuse myself.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: And by despairing shalt thou stand excused,
For doing worthy Vengeance on thyself,
That didst unworthy slaughter upon others.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Say that I slew them not.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Then say they were not slain:
But dead they are, and devilish slave by thee.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: I did not kill your Husband.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Why then he is alive.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Nay, he is dead, and slain by Edwards hands.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: In thy foul throat thou Liest,
Queen Margaret saw
Thy murderous Falchion smoking in his blood:
The which, thou once didst bend against her breast,
But that thy Brothers beat aside the point.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: I was provoked by her slanderous tongue,
That laid their guilt, upon my guiltless Shoulders.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Thou wast provoked by thy bloody mind,
That never dreamest on aught but Butcheries:
Didst thou not kill this King?

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: I grant ye.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Dost grant me Hedgehog,
Then God grant me too
Thou mayst be damned for that wicked deed,
O he was gentle, mild, and virtuous.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: The better for the King of heaven that hath him.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: He is in heaven, where thou shalt never come.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Let him thank me, that holp to send him thither:
For he was fitter for that place than earth.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: And thou unfit for any place, but hell.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Yes one place else, if you will hear me name it.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Some dungeon.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Your Bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Ill rest betide the chamber where thou liest.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: So will it Madam, till I lie with you.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: I hope so.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: I know so. But gentle Lady Anne,
To leave this keen encounter of our wits,
And fall something into a slower method.
Is not the causer of the timeless deaths
Of these Plantagenets, Henrie and Edward,
As blameful as the Executioner.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Thou wast the cause, and most accursed effect.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Your beauty was the cause of that effect:
Your beauty, that did haunt me in my sleep,
To undertake the death of all the world,
So I might live one hour in your sweet bosom.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: If I thought that, I tell thee Homicide,
These Nails should rent that beauty from my Cheeks.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: These eyes could not endure that beauties wrack,
You should not blemish it, if I stood by;
As all the world is cheered by the Sun,
So I by that: It is my day, my life.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Black night ore-shade thy day, and death thy life.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Curse not thyself fair Creature,
Thou art both.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: I would I were, to be revenged on thee.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: It is a quarrel most unnatural,
To be revenged on him that loveth . thee.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: It is a quarrel just and reasonable,
To be revenged on him that killed my Husband.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: He that bereft the Lady of thy Husband,
Did it to help thee to a better Husband.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: His better doth not breathe upon the earth.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: He lives, that loves thee better than he could.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Name him.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Plantagenet.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Why that was he.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: The selfsame name, but one of better Nature.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Here:

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Why dost thou spit at me.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Would it were mortal poison, for thy sake.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Never came poison from so sweet a place.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Never hung poison on a fowler Toad.
Out of my sight, thou dost infect mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Thine eyes (sweet Lady) have infected mine.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Would they were Basilisks, to strike thee dead.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: I would they were, that I might dye at once:
For now they kill me with a living death.
Those eyes of thine, from mine have drawn salt Tears;
Shamed their Aspects with store of childish drops:
These eyes, which never shed remorseful tear,
No, when my Father Yorke, and Edward wept,
To hear the piteous moan that Rutland made
When black-faced Clifford shook his sword at him.
Nor when thy warlike Father like a Child,
Told the sad story of my Father's death,
And twenty times, made pause to sob and weep:
That all the standers-by had wet their cheeks
Like Trees bedashed with rain. In that sad time,
My manly eyes did scorn an humble tear:
And what these sorrows could not thence exhale,
Thy Beauty hath, and made them blind with weeping.
I never sued to Friend, nor Enemy:
My Tongue could never learn sweet smoothing word.
But now thy Beauty is proposed my Fee,
My proud heart sues, and prompts my tongue to speak.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Teach not thy lip such Scorn; for it was made
For kissing Lady, not for such contempt.
If thy revengeful heart cannot forgive,
Lo here I lend thee this sharpe-pointed Sword,
Which if thou please to hide in this true breast,
And let the Soul forth that adoreth thee,
I lay it naked to the deadly stroke,
And humbly beg the death upon my knee,

stage.l: He layes his brest open, she offers at with his sword.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Nay do not pause: For I did kill King Henrie,
But it was thy Beauty that provoked me.
Nay now dispatch: It was I that stabbed young Edward,
But it was thy Heavenly face that set me on.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Take up the Sword again, or take up me.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Arise Dissembler, though I wish thy death,
I will not be thy Executioner.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Then bid me kill myself, and I will do it.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: I have already.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: That was in thy rage:
Speak it again, and even with the word,
This hand, which for thy love, did kill thy Love,
Shall for thy love, kill a far truer Love,
To both their deaths shalt thou be accessory.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: I would I knew thy heart.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: It is figured in my tongue.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: I fear me, both are false.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Then never Man was true.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Well, well, put up your Sword.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Say then my Peace is made.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: That shalt thou know hereafter.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: But shall I live in hope.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: All men I hope live so.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Vouchsafe to wear this Ring.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Look how my Ring encompasseth thy Finger,
Even so thy Breast encloseth my poor heart:
Wear both of them, for both of them are thine.
And if thy poor devoted Servant may
But beg one favour at thy gracious hand,
Thou dost confirm his happiness forever.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: That it may please you leave these sad designs,
To him that hath most cause to be a Mourner,
And presently repair to Crosbie House:
Where (after I have solemnly interred
At Chertsey Monastery this Noble King,
And wet his Grave with my Repentant Tears)
I will with all expedient duty see you,
For divers unknown Reasons, I beseech you,
Grant me this Boon.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: With all my heart, and much it joys me too,
To see you are become so penitent.
Tressel and Barkley, go along with me.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Bid me farewell.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: It is more than you deserve:
But since you teach me how to flatter you,
Imagine I have said farewell already.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Towards Chertsey, Noble Lord?

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: No: to White Friars, there attend my coming

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Was ever woman in this humour wooed?
Was ever woman in this humour won?
I will have her, but I will not keep her long.
What? I that killed her Husband, and his Father,
To take her in her hearts extremest hate,
With curses in her mouth, Tears in her eyes,
The bleeding witness of my hatred by,
Having God, her Conscience, and these bars against me,
And I, no Friends to back my suite withal,
But the plain Devil, and dissembling looks?
And yet to win her? All the world to nothing.
Hah!
Hath she forgot already that brave Prince,
Edward, her Lord, whom I (some three months since)
Stabbed in my angry mood, at Tewkesbury?
A sweeter, and a lovelier Gentleman,
Framed in the prodigality of Nature:
Young, Valiant, Wise, and (no doubt) right Royal,
The spacious World cannot again afford:
And will she yet abase her eyes on me,
That cropped the Golden prime of this sweet Prince,
And made her Widow to a woeful Bed?
On me, whose All not equals Edwards Moiety?
On me, that halts, and am misshapen thus?
My Dukedom, to a Beggarly denier!
I do mistake my person all this while:
Upon my life she finds (although I cannot)
Myself to be a marvelous proper man.
I will be at Charges for a Looking-glass,
And entertain a score or two of Tailors,
To study fashions to adorn my body:
Since I am crept in favour with myself,
I will maintain it with some little cost.
But first I will turn yon Fellow in his Grave,
And then return lamenting to my Love.
Shine out fair Sun, till I have bought a glass,
That I may see my Shadow as I pass.

stage.l: Enter the Queene Mother, Lord Riuers,

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Have patience Madam, there is no doubt his Majesty
Will soon recover his accustomed health.

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.l: In that you brooke it ill, it makes him worse,
Therefore for Gods sake entertain good comfort,
And cheer his Grace with quick and merry eyes

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: If he were dead, what would betide on me?
If he were dead, what would betide on me?

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.l: No other harm, but loss of such a Lord.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: The loss of such a Lord, includes all harms.

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.l: The Heavens have blessed you with a goodly Son,
To be your Comforter, when he is gone.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: Ah! he is young; and his minority
Is put unto the trust of Richard Glouster,
A man that loves not me, nor none of you.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Is it concluded he shall be Protector?

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: It is determined, not concluded yet:
But so it must be, if the King miscarry.

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.l: Here comes the Lord of Buckingham and Derby.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Good time of day unto your Royal Grace.

sp.speaker: Derby.
sp.l: God make your Majesty joyful, as you have been

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: The Countess Richmond, good my Lord. of Derby.
To your good prayer, will scarcely say, Amen.
Yet Derby, notwithstanding she is your wife,
And loves not me, be you good Lord assured,
I hate not you for her proud arrogance.

sp.speaker: Derby.
sp.l: I do beseech you, either not believe
The envious slanders of her false Accusers:
Or if she be accused on true report,
Bear with her weakness, which I think proceeds
From wayward sickness, and no grounded malice.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: Saw you the King today my Lord of Derby.

sp.speaker: Derby.
sp.l: But now the Duke of Buckingham and I,
Are come from visiting his Majesty.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: What likelihood of his amendment Lords.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Madam good hope, his Grace speaks cheerfully.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: God grant him health, did you confer with him?

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Aye Madam, he desires to make atonement:
Between the Duke of Glouster, and your Brothers,
And between them, and my Lord Chamberlain,
And sent to warn them to his Royal presence.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: Would all were well, but that will never be,
I fear our happiness is at the height.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: They do me wrong, and I will not endure it,
Who is it that complains unto the King,
That I (forsooth) am stern, and love them not?
By holy Paul, they love his Grace but lightly,
That fill his ears with such dissentious Rumours.
Because I cannot flatter, and look fair,
Smile in men's faces, smooth, deceive, and cog,
Duck with French nods, and Apish courtesy,
I must be held a rancorous Enemy.
Cannot a plain man live, and think no harm,
But thus his simple truth must be abused,
With silken, sly, insinuating Iackes?

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.l: To who in all this presence speaks your Grace?

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: To thee, that hast nor Honesty, nor Grace:
When have I injured thee? When done thee wrong?
Or thee? or thee? or any of your Faction?
A plague upon you all. His Royal Grace
(Whom God preserve better than you would wish)
Cannot be quiet scarce a breathing while,
But you must trouble him with lewd complaints.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: Brother of Glouster, you mistake the matter:
The King on his own Royal disposition,
(And not provoked by any Suitor else)
Aiming (belike) at your interior hatred,
That in your outward action shows itself
Against my Children, Brothers, and myself,
Makes him to send, that he may learn the ground.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: I cannot tell, the world is grown so bad,
That Wrens make prey, where Eagles dare not perch.
Since every Iacke became a Gentleman,
There is many a gentle person made a Iacke.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: Come, come, we know your meaning Brother (Gloster
You envy my advancement, and my friends:
God grant we never may have need of you.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Mean time, God grants that I have need of you.
Our Brother is imprisoned by your means,
Myself disgraced, and the Nobility
Held in contempt, while great Promotions
Are daily given to ennoble those
That scarce some two days since were worth a Noble.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: By him that raised me to this careful height,
From that contented hap which I enjoyed,
I never did incense his Majesty
Against the Duke of Clarence, but have been
An earnest advocate to plead for him.
My Lord you do me shameful injury,
Falsely to draw me in these vile suspects.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: You may deny that you were not the mean
Of my Lord Hastings late imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: She may my Lord, for---

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: She may Lord Riuers, why who knows not so?
She may do more sir than denying that:
She may help you to many fair preferments,
And then deny her aiding hand therein,
And lay those Honours on your high desert.
What may she not, she may, Aye marry may she.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: What marry may she?

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: What marry may she? Marry with a King,
A Bachelor, and a handsome stripling too,
Iwis your Grandam had a worser match.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: My Lord of Glouster, I have too long borne
Your blunt upbraidings, and your bitter scoffs:
By heaven, I will acquaint his Majesty
Of those gross taunts that oft I have endured.
I had rather be a Country servant maid
Than a great Queen, with this condition,
To be so baited, scorned, and stormed at,
Small joy have I in being Englands Queen.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: And lessened be that small, God I beseech him,
Thy honour, state, and seat, is due to me.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: What? threat you me with telling of the King?
I will avouch it in presence of the King:
I dare adventure to be sent to the Tower.
It is time to speak,
My pains are quite forgot.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Out Devil,
I do remember them too well:
Thou killdest my Husband Henrie in the Tower,
And Edward my poor Son, at Tewkesburie.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Ere you were Queen,
Aye, or your Husband King:
I was a packhorse in his great affairs:
A weeder out of his proud Adversaries,
A liberal rewarder of his Friends,
To royalize his blood, I spent mine own.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Aye and much better blood
Than his, or thine.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: In all which time, you and your Husband Grey
Were factious, for the House of Lancaster;
And Riuers, so were you: Was not your Husband,
In Margaret's Battle, at Saint Albons, slain?
Let me put in your minds, if you forget
What you have been ere this, and what you are:
Withal, what I have been, and what I am.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: A murderous Villain, and so still thou art.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Poor Clarence did forsake his Father Warwicke,
Aye, and forswore himself (which Iesu pardon.)

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Which God revenge.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: To fight on Edwards party, for the Crown,
And for his meed, poor Lord, he is mewed up:
I would to God my heart were Flint, like Edwards,
Or Edwards soft and pitiful, like mine;
I am too childish foolish for this World.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: High thee to Hell for shame, and leave this World
Thou Cacodemon, there thy Kingdom is.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: My Lord of Gloster: in those busy days,
Which here you urge, to prove us Enemies,
We followed then our Lord, our Sovereign King,
So should we you, if you should be our King.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: If I should be? I had rather be a Peddler:
Far be it from my heart, the thought thereof.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: As little joy (my Lord) as you suppose
You should enjoy, were you this Countries King,
As little joy you may suppose in me,
That I enjoy, being the Queen thereof.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: A little joy enjoys the Queen thereof,
For I am she, and altogether joyless:
I can no longer hold me patient.
Hear me, you wrangling Pirates, that fall out,
In sharing that which you have pilled from me:
Which of you trembles not, that looks on me?
If not, that I am Queen, you bow like Subjects;
Yet that by you deposed, you quake like Rebels.
Ah gentle Villain, do not turn away.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Foul wrinkled Witch, what makest thou in my sight?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: But repetition of what thou hast marred,
That will I make, before I let thee go.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Wert thou not banished, on pain of death?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I was: but I do find more pain in banishment,
Than death can yield me here, by my abode.
A Husband and a Son thou owest to me,
And thou a Kingdom; all of you, allegiance:
This Sorrow that I have, by right is yours,
And all the Pleasures you usurp, are mine.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: The Curse my Noble Father laid on thee,
When thou didst Crown his Warlike Brows with Paper,
And with thy scorns drewest Riuers from his eyes,
And then to dry them, gavest the Duke a Clout,
Steeped in the faultless blood of pretty Rutland:
His Curses then, from bitterness of Soul,
Denounced against thee, are all fallen upon thee:
And God, not we, hath plagued thy bloody deed.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: So just is God, to right the innocent.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: O, it was the foulest deed to slay that Babe,
And the most merciless, that ever was heard of.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Tyrants themselves wept when it was reported.

sp.speaker: Dors.
sp.l: No man but prophesied revenge for it.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Northumberland, then present, wept to see it.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: What? were you snarling all before I came,
Ready to catch each other by the throat,
And turn you all your hatred now on me?
Did Yorkes dread Curse prevail so much with Heaven,
That Henries death, my lovely Edwards death,
Their Kingdom's loss, my woeful Banishment,
Should all but answer for that peevish Brat?
Can Curses pierce the Clouds, and enter Heaven?
Why then give way dull Clouds to my quick Curses.
Though not by War, by Surfeit dye your King,
As ours by Murther, to make him a King.
Edward thy Son, that now is Prince of Wales,
For Edward our Son, that was Prince of Wales,
Dye in his youth, by like untimely violence.
Thyself a Queen, for me that was a Queen,
Outlive thy glory, like my wretched self:
Long mayst thou live, to wail thy Children's death,
And see another, as I see thee now,
Decked in thy Rights, as thou art stalled in mine.
Long dye thy happy days, before thy death,
And after many lengthened hours of grief,
Dye neither Mother, Wife, nor Englands Queen.
Riuers and Dorset, you were standers-by,
And so wast thou, Lord Hastings, when my Son
Was stabbed with bloody Daggers: God, I pray him,
That none of you may live his natural age,
But by some unlooked accident cut off.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Have done thy Charm, thou hateful withered Hag.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: And leave out thee? stay Dog, for thou shalt hear me.
If Heaven have any grievous plague in store,
Exceeding those that I can wish upon thee,
O let them keep it, till thy sins be ripe,
And then hurl down their indignation
On thee, the troubler of the poor Worlds peace.
The Worm of Conscience still begnaw thy Soul,
Thy Friends suspect for Traitors while thou livest,
And take deep Traitors for thy dearest Friends:
No sleep close up that deadly Eye of thine,
Unless it be while some tormenting Dream
Affrights thee with a Hell of ugly Devils.
Thou elvish marked, abortive rooting Hog,
Thou that wast sealed in thy Nativity
The slave of Nature, and the Son of Hell:
Thou slander of thy heavy Mothers Womb,
Thou loathed Issue of thy Father's Loins,
Thou Rag of Honour, thou detested---

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Margaret.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Richard.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Rich. Ha.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I call thee not.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: I cry thee mercy then: for I did think,
That thou hadst called me all these bitter names.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Why so I did, but looked for no reply.
O let me make the Period to my Curse.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: It is done by me, and ends in Margaret.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: Thus have you breathed your Curse against yourself.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Poor painted Queen, vain flourish of my fortune,
Why strewest thou Sugar on that Bottled Spider,
Whose deadly Web ensnareth thee about?
Fool, fool, thou whettest a Knife to kill thyself:
The day will come, that thou shalt wish for me,
To help thee curse this poisonous Bunch-backed Toad.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: False boding Woman, end thy frantic Curse,
Lest to thy harm, thou move our patience.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Foul shame upon you, you have all moved mine.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Were you well served, you would be taught your duty.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: To serve me well, you all should do me duty,
Teach me to be your Queen, and you my Subjects:
O serve me well, and teach yourselves that duty.

sp.speaker: Dors.
sp.l: Dispute not with her, she is lunatic.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Peace Master Marquess, you are malapert,
Your fire-new stamp of Honour is scarce currant.
O that your young Nobility could judge
What it were to lose it, and be miserable.
They that stand high, have many blasts to shake them,
And if they fall, they dash themselves to pieces.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Good counsel marry, learn it, learn it Marquess.

sp.speaker: Dors.
sp.l: It touches you my Lord, as much as me.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Aye, and much more: but I was born so high:
Our eyrie buildeth in the Cedars top,
And dallies with the wind, and scorns the Sun.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: And turns the Sun to shade: alas, alas,
Witness my Son, now in the shade of death,
Whose bright out-shining beams, thy cloudy wrath
Hath in eternal darkness folded up.
Your eyrie buildeth in our eyries Nest:
O God that seest it, do not suffer it,
As it is won with blood, lost be it so.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Peace, peace for shame: If not, for Charity.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Urge neither charity, nor shame to me:
Uncharitably with me have you dealt,
And shamefully my hopes (by you) are butchered.
My Charity is outrage, Life my shame,
And in that shame, still live my sorrows' rage.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Have done, have done.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: O Princely Buckingham, I will kiss thy hand,
In sign of League and amity with thee:
Now fair befall thee, and thy Noble house:
Thy Garments are not spotted with our blood:
Nor thou within the compass of my curse.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Nor no-one here: for Curses never pass
The lips of those that breathe them in the air.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I will not think but they ascend the sky,
And there awake God's gentle sleeping peace.
O Buckingham, take heed of yonder dog:
Look when he fawns, he bites; and when he bites,
His venom tooth will rankle to the death.
Have not to do with him, beware of him,
Sin, death, and hell have set their marks on him,
And all their Ministers attend on him.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: What doth she say, my Lord of Buckingham.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Nothing that I respect my gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: What dost thou scorn me
For my gentle counsel?
And sooth the devil that I warn thee from.
O but remember this another day:
When he shall split thy very heart with sorrow:
And say (poor Margaret) was a Prophetess:
Live each of you the subjects to his hate,
And he to yours, and all of you to Gods.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: My hair doth stand on end to hear her curses.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: And so doth mine, I muse why she is at liberty.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: I cannot blame her, by God's holy mother,
She hath had too much wrong, and I repent
My part thereof, that I have done to her.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I never did her any to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Yet you have all the vantage of her wrong:
I was too hot, to do somebody good,
That is too cold in thinking of it now:
Marry as for Clarence, he is well repaid:
He is franked up to fatting for his pains,
God pardon them, that are the cause thereof.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: A virtuous, and a Christian-like conclusion
To pray for them that have done scathe to us.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: So do I ever, being well advised.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: For had I cursed now, I had cursed myself.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Madam, his Majesty doth call for you,
And for your Grace, and yours my gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: Catesby I come, Lords will you go with me.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: We wait upon your Grace.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: I do the wrong, and first begin to brawl.
The secret Mischiefs that I set abroach,
I lay unto the grievous charge of others.
Clarence, who I indeed have cast in darkness,
I do beweep to many simple Gulls,
Namely to Derby, Hastings, Buckingham,
And tell them it is the Queen, and her Allies,
That stir the King against the Duke my Brother.
Now they believe it, and withal whet me
To be revenged on Riuers, Dorset, Grey.
But then I sigh, and with a piece of Scripture,
Tell them that God bids us do good for evil:
And thus I clothe my naked Villainy
With odd old ends, stolen forth of holy Writ,
And seem a Saint, when most I play the devil.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: But soft, here come my Executioners,
How now my hardy stout resolved Mates,
Are you now going to dispatch this thing?

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: We are my Lord, and come to have the Warrant,
That we may be admitted where he is.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Well thought upon, I have it here about me:
When you have done, repair to Crosby place;
But sirs be sudden in the execution,
Withal obdurate, do not hear him plead;
For Clarence is well spoken, and perhaps
May move your hearts to pity, if you mark him.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: Tut, tut, my Lord, we will not stand to prate,
Talkers are no good doers, be assured:
We go to use our hands, and not our tongues.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Your eyes drop Millstones, when Fools' eyes
fall Tears:
I like you Lads, about your business straight.
Go, go, dispatch.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: We will my Noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Brack.
sp.l: Why looks your Grace so heavily today.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O, I have passed a miserable night,
So full of fearful Dreams, of ugly sights,
That as I am a Christian faithful man,
I would not spend another such a night
Though it were to buy a world of happy days:
So full of dismal terror was the time.

sp.speaker: Brack.
sp.l: What was your dream my Lord, I pray you tell me

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower,
And was embarked to cross to Burgundy,
And in my company my Brother Glouster,
Who from my Cabin tempted me to walk,
Upon the Hatches: There we looked toward England,
And cited up a thousand heavy times,
During the wars of Yorke and Lancaster
That had befallen us. As we paced along
Upon the giddy footing of the Hatches,
Methought that Glouster stumbled, and in falling
Struck me (that thought to stay him) overboard,
Into the tumbling billows of the maine.
O Lord, methought what pain it was to drown,
What dreadful noise of water in mine ears,
What sights of ugly death within mine eyes.
Methoughts, I saw a thousand fearful wrecks:
A thousand men that Fishes gnawed upon:
Wedges of Gold, great Anchors, heaps of Pearl,
Inestimable Stones, unvalued Jewels,
All scattered in the bottom of the Sea,
Some lay in dead men's Skulls, and in the holes
Where eyes did once inhabit, there were crept
(As it were in scorn of eyes) reflecting Gems,
That wooed the slimy bottom of the deep,
And mocked the dead bones that lay scattered by.

sp.speaker: Brack.
sp.l: Had you such leisure in the time of death
To gaze upon these secrets of the deep?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Methought I had, and often did I strive
To yield the Ghost: but still the envious Flood
Stopped in my soul, and would not let it forth
To find the empty, vast, and wandering air:
But smothered it within my panting bulk,
Who almost burst, to belch it in the Sea.

sp.speaker: Brack.
sp.l: Awaked you not in this sore Agony?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: No, no, my Dream was lengthened after life.
O then, began the Tempest to my Soul.
I past (methought) the Melancholy Flood,
With that sour Ferry-man which Poets write of,
Unto the Kingdom of perpetual Night.
The first that there did greet my Stranger-soul,
Was my great Father-in-Law, renowned Warwicke,
Who spake aloud: What scourge for Perjury,
Can this dark Monarchy afford false Clarence?
And so he vanished. Then came wandering by,
A Shadow like an Angel, with bright hair
Dabbled in blood, and he shrieked out aloud
Clarence is come, false, fleeting, perjured Clarence,
That stabbed me in the field by Tewkesbury:
Seize on him Furies, take him unto Torment.
With that (methought) a Legion of foul Fiends
Environed me, and howled in mine ears
Such hideous cries, that with the very Noise,
I (trembling) waked, and for a season after,
Could not believe, but that I was in Hell,
Such terrible Impression made my Dream.

sp.speaker: Brack.
sp.l: No marvel Lord, though it affrighted you,
I am afraid (methinks) to hear you tell it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Ah Keeper, Keeper, I have done these things
(That now give evidence against my Soul)
For Edwards sake, and see how he requites me.
O God! if my deep prayers cannot appease thee,
But thou wilt be avenged on my misdeeds,
Yet execute thy wrath in me alone:
O spare my guiltless Wife, and my poor children.
Keeper, I prithee sit by me awhile,
My Soul is heavy, and I fain would sleep.

sp.speaker: Brack.
sp.l: I will my Lord, God give your Grace good rest.

sp.speaker: Brack.
sp.l: Sorrow breaks Seasons, and reposing hours,
Makes the Night Morning, and the Noon-tide night:
Princes have but their Titles for their Glories,
An outward Honour, for an inward Toil,
And for unfelt Imaginations
They often feel a world of restless Cares:
So that between their Titles, and low Name,
There is nothing differs, but the outward fame.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.p: Ho, who is here?

sp.speaker: Brack.
sp.l: What wouldst thou Fellow? And how camest
thou hither.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.p: I would speak with Clarence, and I came hither on my Legs.

sp.speaker: Brack.
sp.l: What so brief?

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.p:
It is better (Sir) than to be tedious:
Let him see our Commission, and talk no more.

sp.speaker: Brack.
sp.l: I am in this, commanded to deliver
The Noble Duke of Clarence to your hands.
I will not reason what is meant hereby,
Because I will be guiltless from the meaning.
There lies the Duke asleep, and there the Keys.
I will to the King, and signify to him,
That thus I have resigned to you my charge.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.p: You may sir, it is a point of wisdom:
sp.l: Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.p: What, shall we stab him as he sleeps.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.p: No: he will say it was done cowardly, when he wakes

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.p: Why he shall never wake, until the great Judgment day.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.p: Why then he will say, we stabbed him sleeping.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.p:
The urging of that word Judgment, hath bred a
kind of remorse in me.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.p: What? art thou afraid?

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.p:
Not to kill him, having a Warrant,
But to be damned for killing him, from the which
No Warrant can defend me.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.p: I thought thou hadst been resolute.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.p: So I am, to let him live.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.p: I will back to the Duke of Glouster, and tell him so.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.p:
Nay, I prithee stay a little:
I hope this passionate humour of mine, will change,
It was wont to hold me but while one tells twenty.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.p: How dost thou feel thyself now?

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.p: Some certain dregs of conscience are yet within me.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.p: Remember our Reward, when the deed is done.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.p: Come, he dies: I had forgot the Reward.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.p: Where is thy conscience now.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.p: O, in the Duke of Glousters purse.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.p:
When he opens his purse to give us our Reward,
thy Conscience flies out.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.p: It is no matter, let it go: There is few or none will
sp.l: entertain it.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.p: What if it come to thee again?

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.p:
I will not meddle with it, it makes a man a Coward:
A man cannot steal, but it accuseth him: A man cannot
Swear, but it Checks him: A man cannot lie with his
Neighbours Wife, but it detects him. It is a blushing
shamefaced spirit, that mutinies in a man's bosom: It
fills a man full of Obstacles. It made me once restore a
Purse of Gold that (by chance) I found: It beggars any
man that keeps it: It is turned out of Towns and Cities for a dangerous thing, and every man that means to
live well, endeavours to trust to himself, and live
without it.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.p:
It is even now at my elbow, persuading me not to
kill the Duke.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.p:
Take the devil in thy mind, and believe him not:
He would insinuate with thee but to make thee sigh.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.p: I am strong framed, he cannot prevail with me.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.p:
Spoke like a tall man, that respects thy reputation.
Come, shall we fall to work?

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.p:
Take him on the Costard, with the hilts of thy
Sword, and then throw him into the Malmesey-Butte in
the next room.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.p: O excellent device; and make a sop of him.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.p: Soft, he wakes.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.p: Strike.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.p: No, we will reason with him.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Where art thou Keeper? Give me a cup of wine.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.l: You shall have Wine enough my Lord anon.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: In Gods name, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: A man, as you are.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: But not as I am Royal.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.l: Nor you as we are, Loyal.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Thy voice is Thunder, but thy looks are humble.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: My voice is now the King's, my looks mine own.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How darkly, and how deadly dost thou speak?
Your eyes do menace me: why look you pale?
Who sent you hither? Wherefore do you come?

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.l: To, to, to---

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: To murther me?

sp.speaker: Murd 1 and 2.
sp.l: Aye, aye.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You scarcely have the hearts to tell me so,
And therefore cannot have the hearts to do it.
Wherein my Friends have I offended you?

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: Offended us you have not, but the King.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I shall be reconciled to him again.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.l: Never my Lord, therefore prepare to dye.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Are you drawn forth among a world of men
To slay the innocent? What is my offence?
Where is the Evidence that doth accuse me?
What lawful Quest have given their Verdict up
Unto the frowning Judge? Or who pronounced
The bitter sentence of poor Clarence death,
Before I be convict by course of Law?
To threaten me with death, is most unlawful.
I charge you, as you hope for any goodness,
That you depart, and lay no hands on me:
The deed you undertake is damnable.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: What we will do, we do upon command.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.l: And he that hath commanded, is our King.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Erroneous Vassals, the great King of Kings
Hath in the Table of his Law commanded
That thou shalt do no murther. Will you then
Spurn at his Edict, and fulfil a Man's?
Take heed: for he holds Vengeance in his hand,
To hurl upon their heads that break his Law.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.l: And that same Vengeance doth he hurl on thee,
For false Forswearing, and for murther too:
Thou didst receive the Sacrament, to fight
In quarrel of the House of Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: And like a Traitor to the name of God,
Didst break that Vow, and with thy treacherous blade,
Unrippest the Bowels of thy Sovereign's Son.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.l: Whom thou wast sworn to cherish and defend.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: How canst thou urge Gods dreadful Law to us,
When thou hast broke it in such dear degree?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Alas! for whose sake did I that ill deed?
For Edward, for my Brother, for his sake.
He sends you not to murther me for this:
For in that sin, he is as deep as I.
If God will be avenged for the deed,
O know you yet, he doth it publicly,
Take not the quarrel from his powerful arm:
He needs no indirect, or lawless course,
To cut off those that have offended him.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: Who made thee then a bloody minister,
When gallant springing brave Plantagenet,
That Princely Novice was struck dead by thee?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: My Brother's love, the Devil, and my Rage.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: Thy Brothers Love, our Duty, and thy Faults,
Provoke us hither now, to slaughter thee.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: If you do love my Brother, hate not me:
I am his Brother, and I love him well.
If you are hired for meed, go back again,
And I will send you to my Brother Glouster:
Who shall reward you better for my life,
Than Edward will for tidings of my death.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.l: You are deceived,
Your Brother Glouster hates you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O no, he loves me, and he holds me dear:
Go you to him from me.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: Aye so we will.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Tell him, when that our Princely Father Yorke,
Blessed his three Sons with his victorious Arm,
He little thought of this divided Friendship:
Bid Glouster think on this, and he will weep.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: Aye Millstones, as he lessoned us to weep.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O do not slander him, for he is kind.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: Right, as Snow in Harvest:
Come, you deceive yourself,
It is he that sends us to destroy you here.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: It cannot be, for he bewept my Fortune,
And hugged me in his arms, and swore with sobs,
That he would labour my delivery.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: Why so he doth, when he delivers you
From this earths thraldom, to the joys of heaven.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.l: Make peace with God, for you must die my Lord.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Have you that holy feeling in your souls,
To counsel me to make my peace with God,
And are you yet to your own souls so blind,
That you will war with God, by murdering me.
O sirs consider, they that set you on
To do this deed, will hate you for the deed.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.l: What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Relent, and save your souls:
Which of you, if you were a Princes Son,
Being pent from Liberty, as I am now,
If two such murtherers as yourselves came to you,
Would not entreat for life, as you would beg
Were you in my distress.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: Relent? no: It is cowardly and womanish.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Not to relent, is beastly, savage, devilish:
My Friend, I spy some pity in thy looks:
O, if thine eye be not a Flatterer,
Come thou on my side, and entreat for me,
A begging Prince, what beggar pities not.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.p: Look behind you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: Take that, and that, if all this will not do,

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: I will drown you in the Malmesey-But within.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.l: A bloody deed, and desperately dispatched:
How fain (like Pilate) would I wash my hands
Of this most grievous murther.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: How now? what meanest thou that thou helpest me
not? By Heaven the Duke shall know how slack you
have been.

sp.speaker: Murd 2.
sp.l: I would he knew that I had saved his brother,
Take thou the Fee, and tell him what I say,
For I repent me that the Duke is slain.

sp.speaker: Murd 1.
sp.l: So do not I: go Coward as thou art.
Well, I will go hide the body in some hole,
Till that the Duke give order for his burial:
And when I have my meed, I will away,
For this will out, and then I must not stay.

stage.l: Enter the King sicke, the Queene, Lord Marquesse

sp.speaker: King Ed.
sp.l: Why so: now have I done a good day's work.
You Peers, continue this united League:
I, every day expect an Embassage
From my Redeemer, to redeem me hence.
And more to peace my soul shall part to heaven,
Since I have made my Friends at peace on earth.
Dorset and Riuers, take each other's hand,
Dissemble not your hatred, Swear your love.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: By heaven, my soul is purged from grudging hate
And with my hand I seal my true heart's Love.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: So thrive I, as I truly swear the like.

sp.speaker: King Ed.
sp.l: Take heed you dally not before your King,
Lest he that is the supreme King of Kings
Confound your hidden falsehood, and award
Either of you to be the other's end.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: So prosper I, as I swear perfect love.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: And I, as I love Hastings with my heart.

sp.speaker: King Ed.
sp.l: Madam, yourself is not exempt from this:
Nor you Son Dorset, Buckingham nor you;
You have been factious one against the other.
Wife, love Lord Hastings, let him kiss your hand,
And what you do, do it unfeignedly.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: There Hastings, I will never more remember
Our former hatred, so thrive I, and mine.

sp.speaker: King Ed.
sp.l: Dorset, embrace him:
Hastings, love Lord Marquess.

sp.speaker: Dors.
sp.l: This interchange of love, I here protest
Upon my part, shall be inviolable.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: And so swear I.

sp.speaker: King Ed.
sp.l: Now Princely Buckingham, seal thou this league
With thy embracements to my wife's Allies,
And make me happy in your unity.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: When ever Buckingham doth turn his hate
Upon your Grace, but with all duteous love,
Doth cherish you, and yours, God punish me
With hate in those where I expect most love,
When I have most need to employ a Friend,
And most assured that he is a Friend,
Deep, hollow, treacherous, and full of guile,
Be he unto me: This do I beg of heaven,
When I am cold in love, to you, or yours.

sp.speaker: King Ed.
sp.l: A pleasing Cordial, Princely Buckingham
Is this thy Vow, unto my sickly heart:
There wanteth now our Brother Gloster here,
To make the blessed period of this peace.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: And in good time,
Here comes Sir Richard Ratcliffe, and the Duke.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Good morrow to my Sovereign King and Queen
And Princely Peers, a happy time of day.

sp.speaker: King Ed.
sp.l: Happy indeed, as we have spent the day:
Gloster, we have done deeds of Charity,
Made peace of enmity, fair love of hate,
Between these swelling wrong incensed Peers.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: A blessed labour my most Sovereign Lord:
Among this Princely heap, if any here
By false intelligence, or wrong surmise
Hold me a Foe: If I unwillingly, or in my rage,
Have aught committed that is hardly borne,
To any in this presence, I desire
To reconcile me to his Friendly peace:
It is death to me to be at enmity:
I hate it, and desire all good men's love,
First Madam, I entreat true peace of you,
Which I will purchase with my duteous service.
Of you my Noble Cousin Buckingham,
If ever any grudge were lodged between us.
Of you and you, Lord Riuers and of Dorset,
That all without desert have frowned on me:
Of you Lord Wooduill, and Lord Scales of you,
Dukes, Earls, Lords, Gentlemen, indeed of all.
I do not know that Englishman alive,
With whom my soul is any jot at odds,
More than the Infant that is borne tonight:
I thank my God for my Humility.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: A holy day shall this be kept hereafter:
I would to God all strifes were well compounded.
My Sovereign Lord, I do beseech your Highness
To take our Brother Clarence to your Grace.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Why Madam, have I offered love for this,
To be so flouted in this Royal presence?
Who knows not that the gentle Duke is dead?

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: You do him injury to scorn his Coarse.

sp.speaker: King Ed.
sp.l: Who knows not he is dead?
Who knows he is?

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: All-seeing heaven, what a world is this?

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Look I so pale Lord Dorset, as the rest?

sp.speaker: Dors.
sp.l: Aye my good Lord, and no man in the presence,
But his red colour hath forsook his cheeks.

sp.speaker: King Ed.
sp.l: Is Clarence dead? The Order was reversed.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: But he (poor man) by your first order dyed,
And that a winged Mercury did bear:
Some tardy Cripple bare the Countermand,
That came too lag to see him buried.
God grant, that some less Noble, and less Loyal,
Nearer in bloody thoughts, and not in blood,
Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did,
And yet go currant from Suspicion.

sp.speaker: Derby.
sp.l: A boon my Sovereign for my service done.

sp.speaker: King Ed.
sp.l: I prithee peace, my soul is full of sorrow.

sp.speaker: Derby.
sp.l: I will not rise, unless your Highness hear me.

sp.speaker: King Ed.
sp.l: Then say at once, what is it thou requests.

sp.speaker: Derby.
sp.l: The forfeit (Sovereign) of my servant's life,
Who slew today a Riotous Gentleman,
Lately attendant on the Duke of Norfolke.

sp.speaker: King Ed.
sp.l: Have I a tongue to doom my Brothers death?
And shall that tongue give pardon to a slave?
My Brother killed no man, his fault was Thought,
And yet his punishment was bitter death.
Who sued to me for him? Who (in my wrath)
Kneeled and my feet, and bid me be advised?
Who spoke of Brother-hood? who spoke of love?
Who told me how the poor soul did forsake
The mighty Warwicke, and did fight for me?
Who told me in the field at Tewkesbury,
When Oxford had me down, he rescued me:
And said dear Brother live, and be a King?
Who told me, when we both lay in the Field,
Frozen (almost) to death, how he did lap me
Even in his Garments, and did give himself
(All thin and naked) to the numb cold night?
All this from my Remembrance, brutish wrath
Sinfully plucked, and not a man of you
Had so much grace to put it in my mind.
But when your Carters, or your waiting Vassals
Have done a drunken Slaughter, and defaced
The precious Image of our dear Redeemer,
You straight are on your knees for Pardon, pardon,
And I (unjustly too) must grant it you.
But for my Brother, not a man would speak,
Nor I (ungracious) speak unto myself
For him poor Soul. The proudest of you all,
Have been beholding to him in his life:
Yet none of you, would once beg for his life.
O God! I fear thy justice will take hold
On me, and you; and mine, and yours for this.
Come Hastings help me to my Closet.
Ah poor Clarence.

stage.l: Exeunt some with K. and Qneen.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: This is the fruits of rashness: Marked you not,
How that the guilty Kindred of the Queen
Looked pale, when they did hear of Clarence death.
O! they did urge it still unto the King,
God will revenge it. Come Lords will you go,
To comfort Edward with our company.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: We wait upon your Grace.

stage.l: Enter the old Dutchesse of Yorke, with the two

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Good Grandam tell us, is our Father dead?

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: No Boy.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Why do weep so oft? And beat your Breast?
And cry, O Clarence, my unhappy Son.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Why do you look on us, and shake your head,
And call us Orphans, Wretches, Castaways,
If that our Noble Father were alive?

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: My pretty Cousins, you mistake me both,
I do lament the sickness of the King,
As loath to lose him, not your Father's death:
It were lost sorrow to wail one that is lost.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Then you conclude, (my Grandam) he is dead:
The King mine Uncle is to blame for it.
God will revenge it, whom I will importune
With earnest prayers, all to that effect.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: And so will I.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Peace children peace, the King doth love you well.
Incapable, and shallow Innocents,
You cannot guess who caused your Father's death.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Grandam we can: for my good Uncle Gloster
Told me, the King provoked to it by the Queen,
Devised impeachments to imprison him;
And when my Uncle told me so, he wept,
And pitied me, and kindly kissed my cheek:
Bad me rely on him, as on my Father,
And he would love me dearly as a child.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Ah! that Deceit should steal such gentle shape,
And with a virtuous Visor hide deep vice.
He is my son, Aye, and therein my shame,
Yet from my dugs, he drew not this deceit.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Think you my Uncle did dissemble Grandam?

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Aye Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I cannot think it. Hark, what noise is this?

stage.l: Enter the Queene with her haire about her ears,

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: Ah! who shall hinder me to wail and weep?
To chide my Fortune, and torment myself.
I will join with black despair against my Soul,
And to myself, become an enemy.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: What means this Scene of rude impatience?

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: To make an act of Tragic violence.
Edward my Lord, thy Son, our King is dead.
Why grow the Branches, when the Root is gone?
Why wither not the leaves that want their sap?
If you will live, Lament: if dye, be brief,
That our swift-winged Souls may catch the King's,
Or like obedient Subjects follow him,
To his new Kingdom of never-changing night.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Ah so much interest have in thy sorrow,
As I had Title in thy Noble Husband:
I have bewept a worthy Husband's death,
And lived with looking on his Images:
But now two Mirrors of his Princely semblance,
Are cracked in pieces, by malignant death,
And I for comfort, have but one false Glass,
That grieves me, when I see my shame in him.
Thou art a Widow: yet thou art a Mother,
And hast the comfort of thy Children left,
But death hath snatched my Husband from mine Arms,
And plucked two Crutches from my feeble hands,
Clarence, and Edward. O, what cause have I,
(Thine being but a moiety of my moan)
To over-go thy woes, and drown thy cries.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Ah Aunt! you wept not for our Father's death:
How can we aid you with our Kindred tears?

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Our fatherless distress was left unmoaned,
Your widow-dolour, likewise be unwept.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: Give me no help in Lamentation,
I am not barren to bring forth complaints:
All Springs reduce their currents to mine eyes,
That I being governed by the watery Moon,
May send forth plenteous tears to drown the World.
Ah, for my Husband, for my dear Lord Edward.

sp.speaker: Children.
sp.l: Ah for our Father, for our dear Lord Clarence.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Alas for both, both mine Edward and Clarence.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: What stay had I but Edward, and he is gone?

sp.speaker: Children.
sp.l: What stay had we but Clarence? and he is gone.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: What stays had I, but they? and they are gone.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: Was never widow had so dear a loss.

sp.speaker: Children.
sp.l: Were never Orphans had so dear a loss.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Was never Mother had so dear a loss.
Alas! I am the Mother of these Griefs,
Their woes are parcelled, mine is general.
She for an Edward weeps, and so do I:
I for a Clarence weeps, so doth not she:
These Babes for Clarence weep, so do not they.
Alas! you three, on me threefold distressed:
Power all your tears, I am your sorrows' Nurse,
And I will pamper it with Lamentation.

sp.speaker: Dors.
sp.l: Comfort dear Mother, God is much displeased,
That you take with unthankfulness his doing.
In common worldly things, it is called ungrateful,
With dull unwillingness to repay a debt,
Which with a bounteous hand was kindly lent:
Much more to be thus opposite with heaven,
For it requires the Royal debt it lent you.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Madam, bethink you like a careful Mother
Of the young Prince your son: send straight for him,
Let him be Crowned, in him your comfort lives.
Drown desperate sorrow in dead Edwards grave,
And plant your joys in living Edwards Throne.

stage.l: Enter Richard, Buckingham, Derbie, Hastings, and Ratcliffe.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Sister have comfort, all of us have cause
To wail the dimming of our shining Star:
But none can help our harms by wailing them.
Madam, my Mother, I do cry you mercy,
I did not see your Grace. Humbly on my knee,
I crave your Blessing.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: God bless thee, and put meekness in thy breast,
Love Charity, Obedience, and true Duty.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Amen, and make me die a good old man,
That is the butt-end of a Mothers blessing;
I marvel that her Grace did leave it out.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: You cloudy-princes, and heart-sorrowing-peers,
That bear this heavy mutual load of Moan,
Now cheer each other, in each others Love:
Though we have spent our Harvest of this King,
We are to reap the Harvest of his Son.
The broken rancour of your high-swollen hates,
But lately splintered, knit, and joined together,
Must gently be preserved, cherished, and kept:
Me seemeth good, that with some little Train,
Forthwith from Ludlow, the young Prince be fet
Hither to London, to be crowned our King.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Why with some little Train,
My Lord of Buckingham?

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Marry my Lord, lest by a multitude,
The new-healed wound of Malice should break out,
Which would be so much the more dangerous,
By how much the estate is green, and yet ungoverned.
Where every Horse bears his commanding Rein,
And may direct his course as please himself,
As well the fear of harm, as harm apparent,
In my opinion, ought to be prevented.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: I hope the King made peace with all of us,
And the compact is firm, and true in me.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: And so in me, and so (I think) in all.
Yet since it is but green, it should be put
To no apparent likely-hood of breach,
Which haply by much company might be urged:
Therefore I say with Noble Buckingham,
That it is meet so few should fetch the Prince.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: And so say I.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Then be it so, and go we to determine
Who they shall be that strait shall post to London .
Madam, and you my Sister, will you go
To give your censures in this business.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: My Lord, whoever journeys to the Prince,
For God sake let not us two stay at home:
For by the way, I will sort occasion,
As Index to the story we late talked of,
To part the Queen's proud Kindred from the Prince.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: My other self, my Counsel's Consistory,
My Oracle, My Prophet, my dear Cousin,
I, as a child, will go by thy direction,
Toward London then, for we will not stay behind.

stage.l: Enter one Citizen at one doore, and another at

sp.speaker: Cit 1.
sp.l: Good morrow Neighbour, whether away so
fast?

sp.speaker: Cit 2.
sp.l: I promise you, I scarcely know myself:
Hear you the news abroad?

sp.speaker: Cit 1.
sp.l: Yes, that the King is dead.

sp.speaker: Cit 2.
sp.l: Ill news byrlady, seldom comes the better:
I fear, I fear, it will prove a giddy world.

sp.speaker: Cit 3.
sp.l: Neighbours, God speed.

sp.speaker: Cit 1.
sp.l: Give you good morrow sir.

sp.speaker: Cit 3.
sp.l: Doth the news hold of good king Edward's death?

sp.speaker: Cit 2.
sp.l: I sir, it is too true, God help the while.

sp.speaker: Cit 3.
sp.l: Then Masters look to see a troublous world.

sp.speaker: Cit 1.
sp.l: No, no, by Gods good grace, his Son shall reign.

sp.speaker: Cit 3.
sp.l: Woe to that Land that is governed by a Child.

sp.speaker: Cit 2.
sp.l: In him there is a hope of Government,
Which in his nonage, counsel under him,
And in his full and ripened years, himself
No doubt shall then, and till then govern well.

sp.speaker: Cit 1.
sp.l: So stood the State, when Henry the sixth
Was crowned in Paris, but at nine months old.

sp.speaker: Cit 3.
sp.l: For then this Land was famously enriched
With politic grave Counsel; then the King
Had virtuous Uncles to protect his Grace.

sp.speaker: Cit 1.
sp.l: Why so hath this, both by his Father and Mother.

sp.speaker: Cit 3.
sp.l: Better it were they all came by his Father:
Or by his Father there were none at all:
For emulation, who shall now be nearest,
Will touch us all too near, if God prevent not.
O full of danger is the Duke of Glouster,
And the Queen's Sons, and Brothers, haught and proud:
And were they to be ruled, and not to rule,
This sickly Land, might solace as before.

sp.speaker: Cit 1.
sp.l: Come, come, we fear the worst: all will be well.

sp.speaker: Cit 3.
sp.l: When Clouds are seen, wise men put on their cloaks;
When great leaves fall, then Winter is at hand;
When the Sun sets, who doth not look for night?
Untimely storms, makes men expect a Dearth:
All may be well; but if God sort it so,
It is more than we deserve, or I expect.

sp.speaker: Cit 2.
sp.l: Truly, the hearts of men are full of fear:
You cannot reason (almost) with a man,
That looks not heavily, and full of dread.

sp.speaker: Cit 3.
sp.l: Before the days of Change, still is it so,
By a divine instinct, men's minds mistrust
Pursuing danger: as by proof we see
The Water swell before a boisterous storm:
But leave it all to God. Whither away?

sp.speaker: Cit 2.
sp.l: Marry we were sent for to the Justices.

sp.speaker: Cit 3.
sp.l: And so was I: I will bear you company.

stage.l: Enter Arch-bishop, yong Yorke, the Queene,

sp.speaker: Roth.
sp.l: Last night I heard they lay at Stony Stratford,
And at Northampton they do rest tonight:
Tomorrow, or next day, they will be here.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: I long with all my heart to see the Prince:
I hope he is much grown since last I saw him.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: But I hear no, they say my son of Yorke
has almost overtaken him in his growth.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: Aye Mother, but I would not have it so.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Why my good Cousin, it is good to grow.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: Grandam, one night as we did sit at Supper,
My Uncle Riuers talked how I did grow
More than my Brother. Aye, quoth my Uncle Glouster,
Small Herbs have grace, great Weeds do grow apace.
And since, methinks I would not grow so fast,
Because sweet Flowers are slow, and Weeds make haste.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold
In him that did object the same to thee.
He was the wretchedest thing when he was young,
So long a growing, and so leisurely,
That if his rule were true, he should be gracious.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: And so no doubt he is, my gracious Madam.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: I hope he is, but yet let Mothers doubt.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: Now by my troth, if I had been remembered,
I could have given my Uncle's Grace, a flout,
To touch his growth, nearer than he touched mine.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: How my young Yorke,
I prithee let me hear it.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: Marry (they say) my Uncle grew so fast,
That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old,
It was full two years ere I could get a tooth.
Grandam, this would have been a biting Jest.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: I prithee pretty Yorke, who told thee this?

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: Grandam, his Nurse.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: His Nurse? why she was dead, ere thou wast borne.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: If it were not she, I cannot tell who told me.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: A parlous Boy: go too, you are too shrewd.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Good Madam, be not angry with the Child.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: Pitchers have ears.

sp.speaker: Roth.
sp.l: Here comes a Messenger: What News?

sp.speaker: Mes 1.
sp.l: Such news my Lord, as grieves me to report.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: How doth the Prince?

sp.speaker: Mes 1.
sp.l: Well Madam, and in health.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: What is thy News?

sp.speaker: Mes 1.
sp.l: Lord Riuers, and Lord Grey,
Are sent to Pomfret, and with them,
Sir Thomas Vaughan, Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Who hath committed them?

sp.speaker: Mes 1.
sp.l: The mighty Dukes, Glouster and Buckingham.

sp.speaker: Roth.
sp.l: For what offence?

sp.speaker: Mes 1.
sp.l: The sum of all I can, I have disclosed:
Why, or for what, the Nobles were committed,
Is all unknown to me, my gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: Aye me! I see the ruin of my House:
The Tiger now hath seized the gentle Hind,
Insulting Tyranny begins to Jutt
Upon the innocent and aweless Throne:
Welcome Destruction, Blood, and Massacre,
I see (as in a Map) the end of all.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Accursed, and unquiet wrangling days,
How many of you have mine eyes beheld?
My Husband lost his life, to get the Crown,
And often up and down my sons were tossed
For me to joy, and weep, their gain and loss.
And being seated, and Domestic broils
Clean over-blown, themselves the Conquerors,
Make war upon themselves, Brother to Brother;
Blood to blood, self against self: O preposterous
And frantic outrage, end thy damned spleen,
Or let me dye, to look on earth no more.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: Come, come my Boy, we will to Sanctuary.
Madam, farewell.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Stay, I will go with you.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: You have no cause.

sp.speaker: Roth.
sp.l: My gracious Lady go,
And thither bear your Treasure and your Goods,
For my part, I will resign unto your Grace
The Seal I keep, and so betide to me,
As well I tender you, and all of yours.
Go, I will conduct you to the Sanctuary.

stage.l: Enter yong Prince, the Dukes of Glocester, and Buckingham,

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Welcome sweet Prince to London,
To your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Welcome dear Cousin, my thoughts Sovereign
The weary way hath made you Melancholy.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: No Uncle, but our crosses on the way,
Have made it tedious, wearisome, and heavy.
I want more Uncles here to welcome me.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Sweet Prince, the untainted vertue of your years
Hath not yet dived into the Worlds deceit:
No more can you distinguish of a man,
Than of his outward show, which God he knows,
Seldom or never jumpeth with the heart.
Those Uncles which you want, were dangerous:
Your Grace attended to their Sugared words,
But looked not on the poison of their hearts:
God keep you from them, and from such false Friends.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: God keep me from false Friends,
But they were none.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: My Lord, the Mayor of London comes to greet
you.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.l: God bless your Grace, with health and
happy days.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I thank you, good my Lord, and thank you all:
I thought my Mother, and my Brother Yorke,
Would long, ere this, have met us on the way.
Fie, what a Slug is Hastings, that he comes not
To tell us, whether they will come, or no.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: And in good time, here comes the sweating
Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Welcome, my Lord: what, will our Mother
come?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: On what occasion God he knows, not I;
The Queen your Mother, and your Brother Yorke,
Have taken Sanctuary: The tender Prince
Would fain have come with me, to meet your Grace,
But by his Mother was perforce with-held.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Fie, what an indirect and peevish course
Is this of hers? Lord Cardinal, will your Grace
Persuade the Queen, to send the Duke of Yorke
Unto his Princely Brother presently?
If she deny, Lord Hastings go with him,
And from her jealous Arms pluck him perforce.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak Oratory
Can from his Mother win the Duke of Yorke,
Anon expect him here: but if she be obdurate
To mild entreaties, God forbid
We should infringe the holy Privilege
Of blessed Sanctuary: not for all this Land,
Would I be guilty of so great a sin.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: You are too senseless obstinate, my Lord,
Too ceremonious, and traditional.
Weigh it but with the grossness of this Age,
You break not Sanctuary, in seizing him:
The benefit thereof is always granted
To those, whose dealings have deserved the place,
And those who have the wit to claim the place:
This Prince hath neither claimed it, nor deserved it,
And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot have it.
Then taking him from thence, that is not there,
You break no Privilege, nor Charter there:
Oft have I heard of Sanctuary men,
But Sanctuary children, never till now.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: My Lord, you shall over-rule my mind for once.
Come on, Lord Hastings, will you go with me?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: I go, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Good Lords, make all the speedy haste you may.
Say, Uncle Glocester, if our Brother come,
Where shall we sojourn, till our Coronation?

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: Where it thinkst best unto your Royal self.
If I may counsel you, some day or two
Your Highness shall repose you at the Tower:
Then where you please, and shall be thought most fit
For your best health, and recreation.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I do not like the Tower, of any place:
Did Julius Cæsar build that place, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: He did, my gracious Lord, begin that place,
Which since, succeeding Ages have re-edified.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Is it upon record? or else reported
Successively from age to age, he built it?

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Upon record, my gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: But say, my Lord, it were not registered,
Methinks the truth should live from age to age,
As it were retailed to all posterity,
Even to the general ending day.

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: So wise, so young, they say do never live long.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: What say you, Uncle?
